plottablesQt.py

Go to the documentation of this file.
00001 """Prototype plottable object support.
00002 
00003 The main point of this prototype is to provide a clean separation between
00004 the style (plotter details: color, grids, widgets, etc.) and substance
00005 (application details: which information to plot).  Programmers should not be
00006 dictating line colours and plotting symbols.
00007 
00008 Unlike the problem of style in CSS or Word, where most paragraphs look
00009 the same, each line on a graph has to be distinguishable from its neighbours.
00010 Our solution is to provide parametric styles, in which a number of
00011 different classes of object (e.g., reflectometry data, reflectometry
00012 theory) representing multiple graph primitives cycle through a colour
00013 palette provided by the underlying plotter.
00014 
00015 A full treatment would provide perceptual dimensions of prominence and
00016 distinctiveness rather than a simple colour number.
00017 """
00018 
00019 # Design question: who owns the color?
00020 # Is it a property of the plottable?
00021 # Or of the plottable as it exists on the graph?
00022 # Or if the graph?
00023 # If a plottable can appear on multiple graphs, in some case the
00024 # color should be the same on each graph in which it appears, and
00025 # in other cases (where multiple plottables from different graphs
00026 # coexist), the color should be assigned by the graph.  In any case
00027 # once a plottable is placed on the graph its color should not
00028 # depend on the other plottables on the graph.  Furthermore, if
00029 # a plottable is added and removed from a graph and added again,
00030 # it may be nice, but not necessary, to have the color persist.
00031 #
00032 # The safest approach seems to be to give ownership of color
00033 # to the graph, which will allocate the colors along with the
00034 # plottable.  The plottable will need to return the number of
00035 # colors that are needed.
00036 #
00037 # The situation is less clear for symbols.  It is less clear
00038 # how much the application requires that symbols be unique across
00039 # all plots on the graph.
00040 
00041 # Support for ancient python versions
00042 if 'any' not in dir(__builtins__):
00043     print "hello"
00044     def any(L):
00045         for cond in L:
00046             if cond: return True
00047         return False
00048     def all(L):
00049         for cond in L:
00050             if not cond: return False
00051         return True
00052 
00053 # Graph structure for holding multiple plottables
00054 class Graph:
00055     """
00056     Generic plottables graph structure.
00057     
00058     Plot styles are based on color/symbol lists.  The user gets to select
00059     the list of colors/symbols/sizes to choose from, not the application
00060     developer.  The programmer only gets to add/remove lines from the
00061     plot and move to the next symbol/color.
00062 
00063     Another dimension is prominence, which refers to line sizes/point sizes.
00064 
00065     Axis transformations allow the user to select the coordinate view
00066     which provides clarity to the data.  There is no way we can provide
00067     every possible transformation for every application generically, so
00068     the plottable objects themselves will need to provide the transformations.
00069     Here are some examples from reflectometry:
00070        independent: x -> f(x)
00071           monitor scaling: y -> M*y
00072           log:  y -> log(y if y > min else min)
00073           cos:  y -> cos(y*pi/180)
00074        dependent:   x -> f(x,y)
00075           Q4:      y -> y*x^4
00076           fresnel: y -> y*fresnel(x)
00077        coordinated: x,y = f(x,y)
00078           Q:    x -> 2*pi/L (cos(x*pi/180) - cos(y*pi/180))
00079                 y -> 2*pi/L (sin(x*pi/180) + sin(y*pi/180))
00080        reducing: x,y = f(x1,x2,y1,y2)
00081           spin asymmetry: x -> x1, y -> (y1 - y2)/(y1 + y2)
00082           vector net: x -> x1, y -> y1*cos(y2*pi/180)
00083     Multiple transformations are possible, such as Q4 spin asymmetry
00084 
00085     Axes have further complications in that the units of what are being
00086     plotted should correspond to the units on the axes.  Plotting multiple
00087     types on the same graph should be handled gracefully, e.g., by creating
00088     a separate tab for each available axis type, breaking into subplots,
00089     showing multiple axes on the same plot, or generating inset plots.
00090     Ultimately the decision should be left to the user.
00091 
00092     Graph properties such as grids/crosshairs should be under user control,
00093     as should the sizes of items such as axis fonts, etc.  No direct
00094     access will be provided to the application.
00095 
00096     Axis limits are mostly under user control.  If the user has zoomed or
00097     panned then those limits are preserved even if new data is plotted.
00098     The exception is when, e.g., scanning through a set of related lines
00099     in which the user may want to fix the limits so that user can compare
00100     the values directly.  Another exception is when creating multiple
00101     graphs sharing the same limits, though this case may be important
00102     enough that it is handled by the graph widget itself.  Axis limits
00103     will of course have to understand the effects of axis transformations.
00104 
00105     High level plottable objects may be composed of low level primitives.
00106     Operations such as legend/hide/show copy/paste, etc. need to operate
00107     on these primitives as a group.  E.g., allowing the user to have a
00108     working canvas where they can drag lines they want to save and annotate
00109     them.
00110 
00111     Graphs need to be printable.  A page layout program for entire plots
00112     would be nice.
00113     """
00114     def xaxis(self,name,units):
00115         """Properties of the x axis.
00116         """
00117         if self.propprop["xunit"] and units != self.propprop["xunit"]:
00118             print "Plottable: how do we handle non-commensurate units"
00119         self.propprop["xlabel"] = "%s (%s)"%(name,units)
00120         self.propprop["xunit"] = units
00121 
00122     def yaxis(self,name,units):
00123         """Properties of the y axis.
00124         """
00125         if self.propprop["xunit"] and units != self.propprop["xunit"]:
00126             print "Plottable: how do we handle non-commensurate units"
00127         self.propprop["ylabel"] = "%s (%s)"%(name,units)
00128         self.propprop["xunit"] = units
00129         
00130     def title(self,name):
00131         """Graph title
00132         """
00133         self.propprop["title"] = name
00134         
00135     def get(self,key):
00136         """Get the graph properties"""
00137         if key=="color":
00138             return self.colorcolor
00139         elif key == "symbol":
00140             return self.symbolsymbol
00141         else:
00142             return self.propprop[key]
00143 
00144     def set(self,**kw):
00145         """Set the graph properties"""
00146         for key in kw:
00147             if key == "color":
00148                 self.colorcolor = kw[key]%len(self.colorlist)
00149             elif key == "symbol":
00150                 self.symbolsymbol = kw[key]%len(self.symbollist)
00151             else:
00152                 self.propprop[key] = kw[key]
00153 
00154     def add(self,plottable):
00155         """Add a new plottable to the graph"""
00156         # record the colour associated with the plottable
00157         self.plottablesplottables[plottable]=self.colorcolor
00158         self.colorcolor += plottable.colors()
00159         
00160     def changed(self):
00161         """Detect if any graphed plottables have changed"""
00162         return any([p.changed() for p in self.plottablesplottables])
00163 
00164     def delete(self,plottable):
00165         """Remove an existing plottable from the graph"""
00166         if plottable in self.plottablesplottables:
00167             del self.plottablesplottables[plottable]
00168 
00169     def reset(self):
00170         """Reset the graph."""
00171         self.colorcolor = 0
00172         self.symbolsymbol = 0
00173         self.propprop = {"xlabel":"", "xunit":None,
00174                      "ylabel":"","yunit":None,
00175                      "title":""}
00176         self.plottablesplottables = {}
00177 
00178     def _make_labels(self):
00179         # Find groups of related plottables
00180         sets = {}
00181         for p in self.plottablesplottables:
00182             if p.__class__ in sets:
00183                 sets[p.__class__].append(p)
00184             else:
00185                 sets[p.__class__] = [p]
00186                 
00187         # Ask each plottable class for a set of unique labels
00188         labels = {}
00189         for c in sets:
00190             labels.update(c.labels(sets[c]))
00191         
00192         return labels
00193 
00194     def render(self,plot):
00195         """Redraw the graph"""
00196         plot.clear()
00197         plot.properties(self.propprop)
00198         labels = self._make_labels_make_labels()
00199         for p in self.plottablesplottables:
00200             p.render(plot,color=self.plottablesplottables[p],symbol=0,label=labels[p])
00201         plot.render()
00202 
00203     def __init__(self,**kw):
00204         self.resetreset()
00205         self.setset(**kw)

00208 # Transform interface definition
00209 # No need to inherit from this class, just need to provide
00210 # the same methods.
00211 class Transform:
00212     """Define a transform plugin to the plottable architecture.
00213     
00214     Transforms operate on axes.  The plottable defines the
00215     set of transforms available for it, and the axes on which
00216     they operate.  These transforms can operate on the x axis
00217     only, the y axis only or on the x and y axes together.
00218     
00219     This infrastructure is not able to support transformations
00220     such as log and polar plots as these require full control
00221     over the drawing of axes and grids.
00222     
00223     A transform has a number of attributes.
00224     
00225     name: user visible name for the transform.  This will
00226         appear in the context menu for the axis and the transform
00227         menu for the graph.
00228     type: operational axis.  This determines whether the 
00229         transform should appear on x,y or z axis context
00230         menus, or if it should appear in the context menu for
00231         the graph.
00232     inventory: (not implemented) 
00233         a dictionary of user settable parameter names and
00234         their associated types.  These should appear as keyword 
00235         arguments to the transform call.  For example, Fresnel 
00236         reflectivity requires the substrate density:
00237              { 'rho': type.Value(10e-6/units.angstrom**2) }
00238         Supply reasonable defaults in the callback so that 
00239         limited plotting clients work even though they cannot 
00240         set the inventory.
00241     """
00242         
00243     def __call__(self,plottable,**kwargs):
00244         """Transform the data.  Whenever a plottable is added
00245         to the axes, the infrastructure will apply all required
00246         transforms.  When the user selects a different representation
00247         for the axes (via menu, script, or context menu), all
00248         plottables on the axes will be transformed.  The
00249         plottable should store the underlying data but set
00250         the standard x,dx,y,dy,z,dz attributes appropriately.
00251         
00252         If the call raises a NotImplemented error the dataline 
00253         will not be plotted.  The associated string will usually
00254         be 'Not a valid transform', though other strings are possible.
00255         The application may or may not display the message to the
00256         user, along with an indication of which plottable was at fault.
00257         """
00258         raise NotImplemented,"Not a valid transform"
00259 
00260     # Related issues
00261     # ==============
00262     #
00263     # log scale:
00264     #    All axes have implicit log/linear scaling options.
00265     # 
00266     # normalization:
00267     #    Want to display raw counts vs detector efficiency correction
00268     #    Want to normalize by time/monitor/proton current/intensity.
00269     #    Want to display by eg. counts per 3 sec or counts per 10000 monitor.
00270     #    Want to divide by footprint (ab initio, fitted or measured).
00271     #    Want to scale by attenuator values.
00272     #
00273     # compare/contrast:
00274     #    Want to average all visible lines with the same tag, and
00275     #    display difference from one particular line.  Not a transform
00276     #    issue?
00277     #
00278     # multiline graph:
00279     #    How do we show/hide data parts.  E.g., data or theory, or 
00280     #    different polarization cross sections?  One way is with
00281     #    tags: each plottable has a set of tags and the tags are
00282     #    listed as check boxes above the plotting area.  Click a
00283     #    tag and all plottables with that tag are hidden on the
00284     #    plot and on the legend.
00285     #
00286     # nonconformant y-axes:
00287     #    What do we do with temperature vs. Q and reflectivity vs. Q
00288     #    on the same graph?
00289     #
00290     # 2D -> 1D:
00291     #    Want various slices through the data.  Do transforms apply
00292     #    to the sliced data as well?
00293 
00294 
00295 class Plottable:
00296     def xaxis(self, name, units):
00297         self._xaxis_xaxis = name
00298         self._xunit_xunit = units
00299 
00300     def yaxis(self, name, units):
00301         self._yaxis_yaxis = name
00302         self._yunit_yunit = units
00303 
00304     @classmethod
00305     def labels(cls,collection):
00306         """
00307         Construct a set of unique labels for a collection of plottables of 
00308         the same type.
00309         
00310         Returns a map from plottable to name.
00311         """
00312         n = len(collection)
00313         map = {}
00314         if n > 0:
00315             basename = str(cls).split('.')[-1]
00316             if n == 1:
00317                 map[collection[0]] = basename
00318             else:
00319                 for i in xrange(len(collection)):
00320                     map[collection[i]] = "%s %d"%(basename,i)
00321         return map
00322     ##Use the following if @classmethod doesn't work
00323     # labels = classmethod(labels)
00324 
00325     def __init__(self):
00326         pass
00327     
00328     def render(self,plot):
00329         """The base class makes sure the correct units are being used for
00330         subsequent plottable.  
00331         
00332         For now it is assumed that the graphs are commensurate, and if you 
00333         put a Qx object on a Temperature graph then you had better hope 
00334         that it makes sense.
00335         """
00336         plot.xaxis(self._xaxis, self._xunit)
00337         plot.yaxis(self._yaxis, self._yunit)
00338         
00339     def colors(self):
00340         """Return the number of colors need to render the object"""
00341         return 1
00342

00344 class Data1D(Plottable):
00345     """Data plottable: scatter plot of x,y with errors in x and y.
00346     """
00347     
00348     def __init__(self,x,y,dx=None,dy=None):
00349         """Draw points specified by x[i],y[i] in the current color/symbol.
00350         Uncertainty in x is given by dx[i], or by (xlo[i],xhi[i]) if the
00351         uncertainty is asymmetric.  Similarly for y uncertainty.
00352 
00353         The title appears on the legend.
00354         The label, if it is different, appears on the status bar.
00355         """
00356         self.xx = x
00357         self.yy = y
00358         self.dxdx = dx
00359         self.dydy = dy
00360 
00361     def render(self,plot,**kw):
00362         Plottable.render(self,plot)
00363         plot.points(self.xx,self.yy,dx=self.dxdx,dy=self.dydy,**kw)
00364 
00365     def changed(self):
00366         return False
00367 
00368     
00369 class Theory1D(Plottable):
00370     """Theory plottable: line plot of x,y with confidence interval y.
00371     """
00372     def __init__(self,x,y,dy=None):
00373         """Draw lines specified in x[i],y[i] in the current color/symbol.
00374         Confidence intervals in x are given by dx[i] or by (xlo[i],xhi[i])
00375         if the limits are asymmetric.
00376         
00377         The title is the name that will show up on the legend.
00378         """
00379         self.xx = x
00380         self.yy = y
00381  
00382         self.dydy = dy
00383 
00384     def render(self,plot,**kw):
00385         plot.curve(self.xx,self.yy,dy=self.dydy,**kw)
00386 
00387     def changed(self):
00388         return False

00392 class Fit1D(Plottable):
00393     """Fit plottable: composed of a data line plus a theory line.  This
00394     is treated like a single object from the perspective of the graph,
00395     except that it will have two legend entries, one for the data and
00396     one for the theory.
00397 
00398     The color of the data and theory will be shared."""
00399 
00400     def __init__(self,data=None,theory=None):
00401         self.datadata=data
00402         self.theorytheory=theory
00403 
00404     def render(self,plot,**kw):
00405         self.datadata.render(plot,**kw)
00406         self.theorytheory.render(plot,**kw)
00407 
00408     def changed(self):
00409         return self.datadata.changed() or self.theorytheory.changed()

00413 def sample_graph():
00414     import numpy as nx
00415     
00416     # Construct a simple graph
00417     if False:
00418         x = nx.array([1,2,3,4,5,6],'d')
00419         y = nx.array([4,5,6,5,4,5],'d')
00420         dy = nx.array([0.2, 0.3, 0.1, 0.2, 0.9, 0.3])
00421     else:
00422         x = nx.linspace(0,1.,10000)
00423         y = nx.sin(2*nx.pi*x*2.8)
00424         dy = nx.sqrt(100*nx.abs(y))/100
00425     data = Data1D(x,y,dy=dy)
00426     data.xaxis('distance', 'm')
00427     data.yaxis('time', 's')
00428     graph = Graph()
00429     graph.title('Walking Results')
00430     graph.add(data)
00431     graph.add(Theory1D(x,y,dy=dy))
00432 
00433     return graph

00435 def demo_plotter_wx(graph):
00436     import wx
00437     #from pylab_plottables import Plotter
00438     from graphics.api.mplwxplotter import Plotter
00439 
00440     # Make a frame to show it
00441     app = wx.PySimpleApp()
00442     frame = wx.Frame(None,-1,'Plottables')
00443     plotter = Plotter(frame)
00444     frame.Show()
00445 
00446     # render the graph to the pylab plotter
00447     graph.render(plotter)
00448     
00449     class GraphUpdate:
00450         callnum=0
00451         def __init__(self,graph,plotter):
00452             self.graph,self.plotter = graph,plotter
00453         def __call__(self):
00454             if self.graph.changed(): 
00455                 self.graph.render(self.plotter)
00456                 return True
00457             return False
00458         def onIdle(self,event):
00459             #print "On Idle checker %d"%(self.callnum)
00460             self.callnum = self.callnum+1
00461             if self.__call__(): 
00462                 pass # event.RequestMore()
00463     update = GraphUpdate(graph,plotter)
00464     frame.Bind(wx.EVT_IDLE,update.onIdle)
00465     app.MainLoop()
00466

00473     # allocation strategy.

00475     app = QtGui.QApplication(sys.argv)
00476     #frame = wx.Frame(None,-1,'Plottables')
00477     plotter = Plotter(parent=0) #plotter is top-level
00478     plotter.show()
00479 
00480     # render the graph to the pylab plotter
00481     graph.render(plotter)

00495             if self.__call__(): 
00496                 pass # event.RequestMore()
